comments.text:
O'RiledUp, Rushboner, and all the other assholes on Fox Noise are to be 
equated with extremist terrorists. They tell overt lies that are 
engendering a violent out-lash by right-wing nutz. Their words have fueled 
hatred of (and by) minorities and women to the point of accepting murder as 
a solution (they reminisce Hitler's final solution.)
I find this to be a major threat to the freedom and well-being of all 
people (and I will defend myself and my family against those bastards) so 
much so that they are criminal and deserving of a life sentence (or end of 
life sentence.) If you try to fuck me or my loved ones over (like the Koch 
(Cock-suck) brothers) then it is either your death or mine.
The 99-percent outnumber the 1-percent. It's time to rise up with our 
pitchforks and send them to the guillotine. Rant over. I feel much better 
now.﻿
comments.author: Timothy Eastman

comments.text:
That short O'Reilly clip there is almost creepy, because it is so much the 
type of propaganda indoctrination material you see in movies about 
totalitarian regimes (or Orwellian, to sum it up) that is almost looks like 
self-parody, as if O'Reilly wants to demonstrate how that would look. The 
fact that he's serious is showing how far the problem has gotten out of 
hand in that country.
Using a strategy of accusing the other of what you are yourself is the 
dumbest move possible, and it's so popular because there are plenty of dumb 
people falling for it.﻿
comments.author: Dᴏᴡʟᴘʜɪɴ

FUX News definitely has the means to employ advanced psychological trickery 
as it is used in marketing.
comments.author: Dᴏᴡʟᴘʜɪɴ

comments.text:
What's even more disturbing, to me at least, is that O'Reilly's talking 
point segment feels like a brainwashing segment. It's hard to explain it 
fully, but the way that he talks, which is a slow and weirdly hypnotic 
tone, as well as the way that he stares at the camera, and the text that's 
scrolling across the screen, which is saying exactly what he's just 
said...it's just creepy and Orwellian in its design.

comments.author: FACTvsEVOLUTION

comments.text:
china, soviet union, cambodia etc were true socialism. people pointing to 
canada,australia,scandanavia etc as socialist is a joke, socialism is 
social control of means of production, 90% of scandanavias economy is 
private control, just because they have high govt spending does NOT mean 
they are socialist.﻿
comments.author: coopmuch56

comments.text:
+Anansi1701 90-95% of the means of production is private in Scandanavia. 
Should we find a balance between rape and making love? No, one is simply 
immoral. Its immoral to initiate the use of force. Which is the ONLY thing 
government does. Taxes are nothing but extortion and theft. Pay me my cut 
or I send men in uniforms to your house to kidnap you and throw you in a 
cage. Laws are nothing but opinions enforced with guns. Dont get that mixed 
up with someone killing someone with no consequence, considered they 
violated the non aggression principle, punishment is justified. Government 
is fundamentally immoral, which means socialism is fundamentally immoral. I 
suggest watching a video titled " the history of your enslavement"  on 
youtube. It sums up what im trying to say.
I didnt assert that canada,australia etc were socialist? I said they WERE 
NOT socialist. And yes human rights are dependent on the system, since the 
only way governement acts is enforcing its will through violence, the 
bigger the government ( the closer to socialism) the more enforcment 
through violence.
comments.author: coopmuch56

comments.text:
+coopmuch56 90-95% is a rather solid number for an ideology with little 
tangible parameters.  Where did you come up with it?
   Canada has a MARKET ECONOMY, but it does still have government 
regulations.  They just focus on the primary issues of the environment, 
prevention of monopolies and protection of consumer.  They still have a 
strong socialist party, the New Democratic Party (NDP) which instead of 
abolishing capitalism sought to reform it.
  He may have been motivated by socialism in the beginning, but if you 
bother to look at what constitutes as socialism, Pol Pot completely failed 
in that regard as it's supposed to be a cooperative endeavor, not something 
forced down someones throat.  At that point it does become a totalitarian 
state and not a socialist one.
   China is CURRENTLY facing massive environmental and social issues.  
Whatever system is in place in China does NOT behave like a socialist, or 
even Marxist communist socio-political system.  The problem with ANY 
economic, social and political systems is that if you have them in extremes 
you see atrophy and abuse.  If they exist on a spectrum you need to find 
the right balance between one form and the other.  That's what Canada and 
Scandinavia have done with accurately aimed regulation and social welfare 
programs like universal healthcare.  WE, the U.S., have regulatory laws 
that to minor to extreme degrees make no sense and have demonized social 
programs because of gross misrepresentations and lack of oversight on those 
programs.
   Socialism opposes freedom as much as capitalism opposes fairness and 
equality?  Bullshit.  Both systems have no opinions on the matter because 
they are simply tools for providing structure.  It's when you introduce the 
human element and let it run rampant that you get instances like in 
Cambodia or the ever growing gap between the wealthy and the poor in this 
country.  Instead of demonizing an entire system, why don't look into, 
figure out what COULD be useful when integrated with another system and 
then discard the rest?
   This conversation started from two points; your initial assertion that 
Canada, Scandinavia and Australia were represented as PURE socialist 
countries and the erroneous connection O'Reilly made between human rights 
laws and political system ideologies.  To the first one, I've presented my 
rebuttal which has some research behind it.  To the second, I would like to 
read your response to that.
comments.author: Anansi1701

comments.text:
"Canada, Scandinavia are not socialist countries.  You're half right for 
they combine many aspects of socialism with free trade"  Its not half and 
half though. Its 90-95% capitalist. Canada has one of the freest makets in 
the world. According to the index of economic freedom Canada is more 
capitalist than America.And how was you say Pol Pot was not motivated by 
socialism? He studied it for years, led a revolution on the ideals, then 
implemented them by force? How is that not motivated by socialism? Yes 
China does have bad conditions, but it was only 20 years ago that they 
implemented more free market policies, which in turn had reduced poverty 
from 85% to 13.7 % in 20 years! That what happens when you give people 
freedom to trade and prosper. Socialism opposes that.
comments.author: coopmuch56

comments.text:
+coopmuch56 What are you saying that I haven't already established?  Though 
I should make an addendum to my previous statement.  No person in their 
right mind would elect fascists OR people who would knowingly orchestrate 
their own suffering.
  I noticed how you said that Canada, Scandinavia are not socialist 
countries.  You're half right for they combine many aspects of socialism 
with free trade.  But just because you're half right here doesn't mean your 
entire comment is vindicated.  Yes, socialism when taken to an extreme can 
cause the horrors seen in Cambodia or Soviet Russia, but the people behind 
those policies were by no means motivated by socialist ideology.  Both 
sought to aggrandize themselves in the annals of history at the expense of 
those they ruled over.  China, as it currently stands, also has some of the 
worst conditions in any developed country as far as the environment and its 
populace are concerned.  In even a slightly socialist country you'd see 
SOME care given to the people and the environment upon which they survive 
on.
   Thank you for showing me where I fell short and have a good day. :)

comments.text:
Ok... so the USSR kept track of those killed in the Gulags (according to 
them...).  What about those killed in to anti-Kulak pogroms?  The 
anti-Jewish pogroms?  Stalin's purge of non-Stalinist Bolsheviks?  
Executions outside of the Gulags?  The USSR killed most of its victims 
outside of the Gulags, not in them.

So... if a government forces people into a career they are non-educated in, 
forces them to use methods that are ineffective, then takes the food from 
them and leaves nothing for them, that is not the governments fault?!?  The 
Ukraine famine is the best documented example of this.  The Soviet 
government organized and controlled the farming, confiscated all of the 
food, and then control the rail stations and roadways to control who and 
what could exit and enter Ukraine.  The Soviet government ate VERY well 
while the Ukrainians starved and this was repeated by all of the other 
Communist governments.  You never see Lenin, Stalin, Mao, or the Kims 
having missed a meal (and their soldiers were fairly well fed also).

The "historians" you list all show their own lack of competence (and your 
gullibility) in their statements.
comments.author: BeukendaalMason

comments.text:
i've never heard of the black book of communism. i do know the records of 
the ussr admit to 2.9 million being executed or starving in the gulags 
between 1917 and 1991. a quick search did find this:

The authors of the book have been criticized for historical inaccuracies. 
Concerning Nicolas Werth's section about Russia, Professor Peter Kenez of 
the University of California wrote about what he says are historical 
inaccurate statements[11]
Werth can also be an extremely careless historian. He gives the number of 
Bolsheviks in October 1917 as 2,000, which is a ridiculous underestimate. 
He quotes from a letter of Lenin to Aleksandr Shliapnikov and gives the 
date as 17 October 1917; the letter could hardly have originated at that 
time, since in it Lenin talks about the need to defeat the Tsarist 
government, and turn the war into a civil conflict. He gives credit to the 
Austro-Hungarian rather than the German army for the conquest of Poland in 
1915. He describes the Provisional Government as "elected."

and:

Historian J. Arch Getty noted that famine accounted for a significant part 
of Courtois's 100 million death toll. He believes that these famines were 
caused by the "stupidity or incompetence of the regime," and that the 
deaths resulting from the famines, as well as other deaths that "resulted 
directly or indirectly from government policy," should not be counted as if 
they were equivalent to intentional murders and executions.[20]
Mark Tauger disagrees with the authors' thesis that the famine of 1933 was 
artificial and genocidal. Tauger asserts that the authors' interpretation 
of the famine contains errors, misconceptions, and omissions that 
invalidate their arguments.[21] However, the historian James Mace wrote 
that Mark Tauger's view of the famine "is not taken seriously by either 
Russians or Ukrainians who have studied the topic."[22] Moreover, Stephen 
Wheatcroft, author of The Years of Hunger, claims Tauger's view represents 
the opposite extreme in arguing the famine was totally accidental.[23]

you don't have to get bogus statistical information from religious sources 
for it to be incorrect.
comments.author: Rembrandt972

comments.text:
+Rembrandt972 The Black Book of Communism is not a religious source for
